Beyond Sen. Sinema's stated opposition to eliminating the filibuster, the scope of this question is pretty limiting. They already did away with the filibuster for approving judges and other administration appointees. The debt ceiling requires action in the House as well. New bills require action outside of the Senate.
GOP will not stick together. Dems will previal
Dem senate does not have enough vote to change the current rule. Also, Nov 2022 is likely a bad news for Dem senate since they may not have majority anymore.
maintaining current forecast! Closely being watched for changes in positions.

While 74 of the 100 Senator incumbents have voted to change the filibuster at least once, Senator Manchin has consistently voted against changes to filibusters, even those that would benefit his party. The likelihood of change while he is in office seems slim. Republicans are likely to take over the Senate at the midterms, with new members being seated January 3, 2023 -- after the date given in the question. The odds appear slim barring some large concession to either Senator Manchin or Senator Sinema (or both being out with covid at the time of a vote..?).

Everybody does know that the second my party's thugs and puppets take over the Senate they will abandon their high principles and modify the filibuster rules in whatever way they think will be to their short-term advantage, right? This will surprise nobody except the Honourable Members for Arizona and West Virginia.

Disregard the previous forecast. I meant to bump it down, NOT up. I do not believe Dems will win that battle BEFORE 1 Jan 2023 as long as Democratic Senator Joe Manchin is in the way. He is not expected to lose his seat before Jan.
Only bumping my forecast up slightly.

Does not seem like there is enough agreement to be able to make a change of this sort and the status quo will weigh heavy on any efforts to change it. Any attempts to change things could put pressure on mid term elections, so I suspect many who are running and in competitive places, won't want to put their neck out on this item.

I think the way people subconsciously synthetize information is one of the great mysteries of life. I've adjusted many of my forecasts after Breyers announcement because I think people recognize the reverberations from his decision. The crowd consensus for Breyer retiring maybe didn't put enough weight on the fact that he is a human too that is susceptible to relentless pressure. He said over and over he wasn't retiring, and yet...Is it possible that Breyer retiring will cause Manchin and Sinema to soften a little? They would never admit this was a reason...
This seems to be the hill Kristen Sinema wants to die on and she doesn't face reelection until 2024.

Two options for changing the filibuster rule - only one feasible/possible: 1) Change text of Senate rule 22. Requires 2/3 support of all Senators present and voting. Based on the 50-50 split of the Senate this is infeasible/impossible given the current ideological split of the Senate as the Republicans have staked out a position against changing the filibuster, and the Democrats have staked out the opposite side of that position. 2) Invoke the nuclear option. Doing so would require a simple majority of 51 Senators to amend the filibuster. Two Democratic Senators - Manchin-D-WV and Sinema-D-AZ - have both stated (on multiple occasions) opposition to changing the filibuster - meaning a very low probability of achieving a simple majority. Neither Manchin or Sinema are up for re-election in the 2022 mid-terms, and there are few electoral disincentives for them to hold this line based on the purple nature of their electorates. But still possible.
Glad that GJ fixed the rules on this market after screwing up the previous one.
In the current Senate unless both Sinema and Manchin have a change of attitude, this approaches zero.
(no change) Interesting article:

The Senate tradition of unlimited debate has allowed for the use of the filibuster. The utility of the filibuster is debatable, but breaking from Senate tradition is a harder nut to crack. Senate traditions are why most electors hold it in higher regard (more stable) than the House of Representatives. Breaking tradition will be difficult, because of the filibuster or any other tradition shifting issue.
The filibuster is probably on life-support, but makes it through this year.
That's laughable.

Although this is becoming a more popular issue, it is extremely difficult to change Senate rules because they are internally established and the existing rules grant power to the minority as well as the majority, unlike the House. If there are any changes, they are unlikely to be sustained as Republicans may soon regain the Senate in upcoming elections. The Senate is also sensitive to sustaining the power of individual Senators and a primary tool is the filibuster.

It does not seem likely given how entrenched the players have become, however there is always a small possibility for an unforeseen change in the power balance between all parties involved. A change of filibuster process rules - thus not changing the scope of matters exempt from the filibuster - appears more probable.

The Democrats need at least two Republicans to make up for the lack of support from Senator Manchin and Sinema. I don’t see who those Republicans are. Nothing significant will happen prior to the mid-term elections. In the time after that, about six weeks, it’s possible that Republicans who lose their seats could flip - maybe Pat Toomey of Pennsylvania or Rob Portman of Ohio, who are both retiring - but probably not.

The Filibuster is a means for the minority party to control the dialog. While the Democrats are currently the "majority" party, they will not be, come midterms, and they won't give up the inherent power of the filibuster. At most they might require a talking filibuster, make the idiots pay with perseverance rather than a simple motion.
Initial forecast. No evidence that they will be any more successful on this than on the removal of the filibuster.

I have been wrong about this consistently. I assumed that passing legislation would triumph; especially when even some conservative commentators have suggested changes that improve Senate functioning. The recent Democrat faceplant also could be seen as the beginning of the next phase of legislating, especially in the NEXT lame duck (Nov - Dec 2022) period. A parting vote would have fewer repercussions...

This is a great question, as it's relevant to a lot of follow-on domestic political questions. Why did Sens Sinema and Manchin recently balk at this vote? There must have been intense pressure/promises from both sides for their votes, and they probably found GOP promises more appealing. What could those promises have been? Could have been promises to field weak candidates against them in their next elections (2024 for both), assuring their reelection in tough states for Dems to win. Maybe that's too big a promise if the GOP thinks they have a realistic chance to win those seats? So can Dem leaders promise them something in the next few weeks that would cause them to change their minds and allow the Dems to take up this vote again before the 2022 midterms? Despite some noise by a couple of members, I'm not sure Dems consider voting rights sufficiently important to overcome their differences and mount an all-out effort to entice Sinema and/or Manchin to their side.
Seems unlikely given the fine balance of the Senate and the positions of Manchin and Sinema. No Republicans are going to back this.
Got my dates mixed up a little. Even if Republicans win control this year, they wouldn't assume office until later in January. So only Democrats would change it, which seems unlikely

Any GOP member doing so at this current time would be crucified and may help Dems more than GOP (as even if they had congress control Biden could just veto). Manchin and Sinema are two big holdouts, and while there is pressure to break fillibuster to do stuff, it seems the cards are in the hands of anyone who votes no - which ahppens to be those two. Some senators may also privately have reservations but aren't willing to be a tall poppy about it
But only if Dems gain a seat or two (to lock in voting rights act before 2024 ). Or maybe if Repubs gain seven or eight seats and their preferred candidate has pending criminal charges.

Every Republican is dead-set against weakening the filibuster as they are currently the minority party and do not want to circumscribe the use of this procedure. This opposition is unlikely to change while they remain the minority party. Joe Manchin and Kirsten Sinema have been under enormous pressure to support weakening the filibuster however have stated publicly numerous times that they are opposed to such measures and joined the GOP senators to vote down a change in filibuster rules on January 19.

Currently, this seems like a 0% chance. The more Sinema and Manchin are pressured, the more determined they become not to budge on filibuster reform. The filibuster historically favors the Republican party, so I think it is in their interests to keep it around. Although, in the event they regain senate control in 2022, what issues would arise to the level of wanting filibuster reform (among Republicans)? It's hard to make a level-headed prediction on that, in the midst of the constant culture wars. My gut wants to say something like anti-CRT or voting issues, but I really don't know.
Seems unlikely - yet there always seem to be new "important" things that pop up (mostly involving big $$$; nothing so trivial as voting rights [sarcasm font]).
(no change) As far as I heard, the "talking filibuster" was not on the agenda last week. OTOH several Senators suggest it is a fond memory and an easy vote.
